title: How to Bake a Tarte Tatin

steps.headline: Roll the pastry sheet into a 101/2-inch square on a floured work surface with a floured rolling pin.
steps.description: Clear off extra flour and cut out a 10-inch round with a sharp knife, while using a plate as a guide. Convey round to a biscuit tin and let chill.

steps.headline: Daub the butter abundantly on the bottom and on the side of the skillet and pour sugar steadily over the bottom.
steps.description: Coordinate as many apples as will fit vertically on the sugar, packing them securely in the concentric circles. The apples will protrude above the border of the skillet.

steps.headline: Cook the apples over fairly high heat, untouched, till the apples juices are a deep golden and boiling, for about 18 to 25 minutes.
steps.description: (Don't worry if juices color unevenly. That tends to happen.)

steps.headline: Put the skillet in center of oven length and breadth of a fragment of foil to capture any drips.
steps.description: Let it bake for 20 minutes (while it does, the apple will settle slightly), then remove from oven and lay the pastry around over the apples.

steps.headline: Bake the tart until  the pastry is a slight browned, at 20 to 25 minutes.
steps.description: Then you move the skillet to a rack and let cool at best 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Just before serving, capsize a salver with lip over skillet and, using potholders to grip the skillet and plate firmly together and turn upside down the tart onto the platter.
steps.description: Substitute any apples that is literally glued to skillet. (Don't worry if there are black spots; they won't modify the flavor of the tart.) Brush any surplus caramel from the skillet over the apples. Serve the dessert promptly after.

text: Preheat oven to 425°F/220°C.  Roll the pastry sheet into a 101/2-inch square on a floured work surface with a floured rolling pin. Clear off extra flour and cut out a 10-inch round with a sharp knife, while using a plate as a guide. Convey round to a biscuit tin and let chill. Daub the butter abundantly on the bottom and on the side of the skillet and pour sugar steadily over the bottom. Coordinate as many apples as will fit vertically on the sugar, packing them securely in the concentric circles. The apples will protrude above the border of the skillet. Cook the apples over fairly high heat, untouched, till the apples juices are a deep golden and boiling, for about 18 to 25 minutes. (Don't worry if juices color unevenly. That tends to happen.) Put the skillet in center of oven length and breadth of a fragment of foil to capture any drips. Let it bake for 20 minutes (while it does, the apple will settle slightly), then remove from oven and lay the pastry around over the apples. Bake the tart until  the pastry is a slight browned, at 20 to 25 minutes. Then you move the skillet to a rack and let cool at best 10 minutes. Just before serving, capsize a salver with lip over skillet and, using potholders to grip the skillet and plate firmly together and turn upside down the tart onto the platter. Substitute any apples that is literally glued to skillet. (Don't worry if there are black spots; they won't modify the flavor of the tart.) Brush any surplus caramel from the skillet over the apples. Serve the dessert promptly after.
